sen.j: 土師器（はじき）とは、弥生式土器の流れを汲み、古墳時代～奈良時代・平安時代まで生産され、中世・近世のかわらけに取って代わられるまで生産された素焼きの土器である。
sen.e: Haji pottery is a type of earthenware that evolved from Yayoi-type pottery and was produced from the Kofun to Nara & Heian periods, until replaced by kawarake earthenware in the medieval and early modern times.

Haji pottery is a type of earthenware that evolved from Yayoi-type pottery and was produced from the Kofun (tumulus) to Nara and Heian periods, until replaced by Kawarake earthenware in the medieval and early modern times.
sen.cmt: 古墳時代 補足を追加しました。
sen.e: Haji pottery is a type of earthenware that evolved from Yayoi-type pottery and was produced from the Kofun (tumulus) to Nara and Heian periods, until replaced by Kawarake earthenware in the medieval and early modern times.

sen.j: 須恵器と同じ時代に並行して作られたが、土師器のほうが品質的に下であった。
sen.e: The pottery was made in the same age as sueki (unglazed earthenware) but was inferior in quality to sueki pottery.
The pottery was made in the same age as Sue pottery (unglazed earthenware) but was inferior in quality to Sue pottery.
sen.cmt: 土師器 と表現を統一し、sue pottery としました。
sen.e: The pottery was made in the same age as Sue pottery (unglazed earthenware) but was inferior in quality to Sue pottery.
Haniwa is also Haji pottery.
Haniwa is also Haji pottery.
Haniwa is also Haji pottery.

sen.j: 多く生産されたのは甕等の貯蔵用具だが、9世紀中頃までは坏や皿などの供膳具もそれなりに生産されていた。
sen.e: Although made mostly as pots and other storage containers, it was also used as bowls, plates and other wares used in making offerings to divinities until the mid-9th century.
Although made mostly as pots and other storage containers, it was also used as bowls, plates and other wares used in making offerings to divinities until the mid-ninth century.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。
sen.e: Although made mostly as pots and other storage containers, it was also used as bowls, plates and other wares used in making offerings to divinities until the mid-ninth century.

sen.j: 炊飯のための道具としては、甑がある。
sen.e: For cooking rice, the "koshiki" was used.
For cooking rice, the "koshiki" was used.
For cooking rice, the "koshiki" was used.

sen.j: 小さな土器焼成坑を地面に掘って焼成するので、密閉性はなく酸素の供給がされる酸化焔焼成によって焼き上げる。
sen.e: The pottery is not airtight and is made by firing with oxidizing flame in a small pottery oven dug on the ground.
The pottery is not airtight and is made by firing with oxidizing flame in a small pottery oven dug on the ground.
The pottery is not airtight and is made by firing with oxidizing flame in a small pottery oven dug on the ground.

sen.j: そのため、焼成温度は須恵器に劣る600～750度で焼成されることになり、橙色ないし赤褐色を呈し、須恵器にくらべ軟質である。
sen.e: For this reason, firing occurs at 600 to 750 degrees, lower than for sueki, creating pottery that is either orange or rust-colored and softer than sueki.
For this reason, firing occurs at 600 to 750 degrees, lower than for Sue pottery, creating pottery that is either orange or rust-colored and softer than Sue pottery.
sen.cmt: 土師器 と表現を統一し、sue pottery としました。
sen.e: For this reason, firing occurs at 600 to 750 degrees, lower than for Sue pottery, creating pottery that is either orange or rust-colored and softer than Sue pottery.

sen.j: 古墳時代に入ってからは、弥生土器に代わって土師器が用いられるようになった。
sen.e: Haji was used in place of Yayoi pottery in the Kofun Period.
Haji was used in place of Yayoi pottery in the Kofun period.
sen.cmt: period を小文字にしました。
sen.e: Haji was used in place of Yayoi pottery in the Kofun period.

sen.j: 土師器の土器形式として庄内式とか布留式（奈良県天理市布留遺跡から出土）とか命名され、庄内式土器の方が古い段階の土師器とされた。
sen.e: Haji has been classified by shape into Shonai type and Furu type (excavated from Furu Site in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture), with the Shonai type regarded the older type of Haji pottery.
Haji has been classified by shape into Shonai type and Furu type (excavated from Furu Site in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture), with the Shonai type regarded the older type of Haji pottery.
Haji has been classified by shape into Shonai type and Furu type (excavated from Furu Site in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture), with the Shonai type regarded the older type of Haji pottery.

sen.j: この庄内式土器の段階では定型化した大型の円墳は未だ出現していなかった。
sen.e: When Shonai type pottery was still used, there were no large tumuli showing consistency in form.
When Shonai type pottery was still used, there were no large tumuli showing consistency in form.
When Shonai type pottery was still used, there were no large tumuli showing consistency in form.

sen.j: つまり庄内式土器は、古墳出現以前の土器であると推定できる。
sen.e: This suggests that Shonai type pottery dates back to the period prior to the age of tumulus construction.
This suggests that Shonai type pottery dates back to the period prior to the age of tumulus construction.
This suggests that Shonai type pottery dates back to the period prior to the age of tumulus construction.

sen.j: 土器形式の古さは弥生V期、庄内式、布留式という順序になる。
sen.e: In chronological order, Yayoi V type is regarded the oldest, followed by Shonai type and later by Furu type.
In chronological order, Yayoi V type is regarded the oldest, followed by Shonai type and later by Furu type.
In chronological order, Yayoi V type is regarded the oldest, followed by Shonai type and later by Furu type.

sen.j: 須恵器とほぼ同時期に生産されていたものであるが、土師器の技法は弥生式土器の延長線上にあり、どの形式から土師器かを土器自体から決定することは難しい。
sen.e: Although roughly identical in age as sueki, Haji pottery is an evolved form of Yayoi type pottery and is extremely difficult to determine at one point Haji pottery starts.
Although roughly identical in age as Sue pottery, Haji pottery is an evolved form of Yayoi type pottery and therefore is extremely difficult to determine from which type Haji pottery started.
sen.cmt: 土師器 と表現を統一し、sue pottery としました。後半の表現を一部変更しました。
sen.e: Although roughly identical in age as Sue pottery, Haji pottery is an evolved form of Yayoi type pottery and therefore is extremely difficult to determine from which type Haji pottery started.

sen.j: 当初は古墳に伴うという時代的特徴が手がかりとなったが、現在では、全国的斉一性が重視されている。
sen.e: Initially, occurrence with tumuli was regarded its distinctive historical features, but the emphasis today is on nationwide occurrence.
Initially, occurrence with tumuli was regarded its distinctive historical features, but the emphasis today is on nationwide occurrence.
Initially, occurrence with tumuli was regarded its distinctive historical features, but the emphasis today is on nationwide occurrence.

sen.j: 縄文式土器、弥生式土器は地域色が強かったのに対し、土師器では、厳密に言えば地方色もあるが、同じような意匠・技法による土器が本州から九州までの規模で分布する。
sen.e: In contrast to Jomon and Yayoi types that were strongly regional in characteristic, Haji is found distributed widely in Honshu and Kyushu islands, based on identical design and production method, though some regional traits can also be found if scrutinized closely.

In contrast to Jomon and Yayoi types that were strongly regional in characteristic, Haji is found distributed widely from Honshu to Kyushu islands, based on identical design and production method, although some regional traits can also be found if scrutinized closely.
sen.cmt: from Honshu to Kyushu としました。
sen.e: In contrast to Jomon and Yayoi types that were strongly regional in characteristic, Haji is found distributed widely from Honshu to Kyushu islands, based on identical design and production method, although some regional traits can also be found if scrutinized closely.

sen.j: これは、前代と一線を画すような文化交流の増大を意味し、その裏に政治的統一の進展を見る説が有力である。
sen.e: This development signifies that there was dramatic growth of cultural exchange unheard of in the previous age and suggests also that advances have been made in political unification.
This strongly supports the theory that there was dramatic growth of cultural exchange unheard of in the previous age, behind which advances were made in political unification.
sen.cmt: have been→ were としました。一部表現を変更しました。
sen.e: This strongly supports the theory that there was dramatic growth of cultural exchange unheard of in the previous age, behind which advances were made in political unification.

sen.j: 9世紀以降は土師器工人集団（土師部）と須恵器工人集団（陶部）との交流が活発になり、轆轤土師器、土師質土器などと呼ばれる両者の中間様式の土器が多量につくられるようになった。
sen.e: In the 9th century, exchange between groups of Haji craftsmen (Hajibe) and Sueki craftsmen (Tobe) grew, resulting in the creation of a large volume of earthenware that is midway between the two in terms of design, such as Rokuro-haji and Haji-shitsu pottery.

From the ninth century, exchange between groups of Haji craftsmen (Hajibe) and Sue craftsmen (Tobe) grew, resulting in the creation of a large volume of earthenware that is midway between the two in terms of design, such as Rokuro-haji and Haji-shitsu pottery.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。
sen.e: From the ninth century, exchange between groups of Haji craftsmen (Hajibe) and Sue craftsmen (Tobe) grew, resulting in the creation of a large volume of earthenware that is midway between the two in terms of design, such as Rokuro-haji and Haji-shitsu pottery.
